awd_titl_txt: IDBR:  Type A.  Photovoltaics allow ultra-miniaturized, long-life, wildlife tags
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Cornell University to fund a dramatic increase in the kinds and numbers of vertebrate species that can be tracked and monitored by the development of a new generation of lightweight yet highly functional tags.  The work of the TABER (Technology for Animal Biology and Environmental Research) group at Cornell is like a real-life project team for engineering students. In the course of this project, the principal investigator and professional engineers will interact with at least a dozen engineering students, and they will interact with biologists and professional engineers in designing and producing devices that will be applied immediately to answer real-world questions about wildlife biology and conservation. This will give students a distinctive chance to have their design efforts make a difference outside Cornell. Because of the structure of the dissemination plan, the roll out of each new design is part of the research of collaborating scientists around the world, and this use has broader impacts in both basic and applied biology and ecology and "word of mouth" circulation among potential users and collaborators world-wide.  A graduate student will be funded to make environmental sensors available to a very wide audience by producing multi-purpose boards to be distributed on Seeed Studio, along with instructional materials on sensor design and construction techniques. News of the project's progress will be passed whenever possible through a network of highly effective communication colleagues in the Colleges of Engineering and Agriculture and Life Sciences and the Education and Multimedia groups at the Cornell Lab of Ornithology.

Through the development of a General-purpose Programmable Tag (GPT) and a Digital Turnstile Tag (DTT), this project will extend the limits of how small extremely long-lived tags can be.  The GPT functions much like traditional beeper tags, with limited abilities to telemeter data, but small size (ca. 0.4 g) and a lifespan longer than that of most birds. Proposed improvements in tag design and antenna placement should dramatically decrease problems for birds wearing the tags, and the proposed information infrastructure that will follow the tags from programming to deployment should make the tag id data highly functional and reliable for all users. This tag has the potential to revolutionize the real-time monitoring of bird migration and the study of dispersal. The proposed DTT would decline to as little as 1 g in mass, and, though it will be optimized to collect solar geolocation data at first, the same platform could be used for an extremely broad array of sensing applications in an open-ended Lab-on-a-Bird platform. In its geolocation function, the DTT would leverage all the progress that has been made recently with geolocation loggers and extend dramatically the range of species to which the technology can be applied by removing the requirement for repeat capture for data recovery in a very small package.

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to develop and expand the capabilities of small solar-powered radio tags for tracking the movements of small birds and other small animals. These tags replace the battery used on traditional wildlife tags with an energy source that consists of a small solar panel and associated circuitry. This allows the tags to be made smaller with much longer active life-times than previous tags. The company which has licensed this tag (Cellular Tracking Technologies) is marketing these tags as “LifeTags”, since they have an anticipated life time of service that equals or exceeds the lifespans of the birds to which they can now be attached.  The circuitry on these tags is controlled by a microprocessor, a tiny electronic chip that has processing abilities that exceed the capabilities of desk top computers a decade ago, and this project explored the use of this microprocessor to do more than merely broadcast a unique digital identification code for each tag. We explored the use of the microprocessor to store light level data from a tiny on-board sensor and transmit that data from the tag’s memory back to a receiving ground station when queried by the station to do so. We pursued this research with a staff engineer working with a team of engineering students at Cornell University. Though we did not get the entire system to work, we managed to prove the feasibility of many of the links in this system design, and we remain confident that a working system to relay on-board sensor data to base stations is well within the realm of these solar-powered nanotags in the future.

 

            One of the challenges of working with radio tags on small birds is that the long whip antennas traditionally used on these tags are bulky and disturb the movements of birds, sometimes even getting caught in branches, etc. To try to solve this problem, this project explored the transmission efficiency of a series of alternative antenna designs, all printed on flexible circuit substrate that would allow the tags to be deployed as a unit with a much smaller footprint and much less disturbance to the birds wearing them.  In this project we helped design over a dozen alternative designs and evaluated them in a series of standardized tests on dummies filled with salt water to mimic the electrical properties of a live bird. Unfortunately, none of the designs came close to having the transmission efficiency of the traditional whip design, and our tests also indicated that feathers overhanging the antennas of the alternative printed designs substantially reduced their transmission strength. Our work has not exhausted the universe of potential alternative designs to the traditional whip antenna, but it has gone a long way in pointing the way to the next alternative designs to be tried.

 

            Another goal of our research was to help the development of some field studies using LifeTags to help show the research community the potential of these new tag designs.  We provided some equipment and field consulting to a team of researchers studying the parental behavior of Chilean Swallows nesting near San Carlos de Bariloche, Argentina. The system worked well there, and it had the potential to enrich greatly the researchers’ understanding of parental foraging movements associated with provisioning their chicks with food, but these small swallows did not accept the tags well, and we decided not to disturb them further.  We also helped develop a network of receivers in the US Carolinas to record the annual movements of tagged Tree Swallows. This species has only been nesting in this region over the last decade as part of a general movement south of this species’ breeding range, and, with our colleague Mark Stanback at Davidson College, we were interested in studying the movements of birds on the edge of their range, wondering whether some birds nesting in areas where northerly nesting birds spend the winter might actually cease migrating all together and remain in the Carolinas as a resident year-round. We installed several receivers in the growing Motus network of radio receivers, but problems in interfacing these receivers with the rapidly growing network and providing enough maintenance supervision of the receivers handicapped our ability to track the relatively few swallows that we tagged in the region.

 

            Even though we failed to achieve various specific research objectives, there was much learned in our failures, and the fact that these tags are being licensed, refined and marketed by an active bird-tag manufacturer sustains the high potential that the research conducted here will serve as important foundation in the further refinement and development of solar-powered nanotags in the future.

 


Last Modified: 12/21/2022
Modified by: Jeremy B Searle
